results.title: Cringe and they'll come running: an environmental study
results.creator_credit: Skin and Hair Flick Co, Experimental Film and Television Fund and Bill Meyer
results.brief_description: In this film, a broad spectrum of well-known contemporary Melbourne artists comment on their own work, their relationships with other artists, and the nature of Australian art. Focuses on the relationship between art and the environment, contrasting urban with the rural landscape, and realism with modernism and conceptualism. Shows the art of sculpture blending into the city landscape and includes many visual images of Melbourne city and suburbs such as the newly opened Tullamarine Airport, National Gallery of Victoria, the freeways and overpasses and high-rise development constructed during the sixties, local art galleries and museums as well as outer Melbourne bush and bayside scenes. Artists include: Bruce Pollard, John Brack, Kevin Gronow, Alun Leach-Jones, Clifford Last, Ruth McNicoll, Lenton Parr, Jan Senbergs, Guy Stuart, Trevor Kretchmar, Andrew Sibley, Dennis Spiteri, Fred Williams and others. Contains some B&W footage.

results.title: Crimes of carelessness
results.brief_description: Depicts the appalling loss of life and property which results from preventable fires. The principle unsafe practices which cause fires are illustrated - then safe ways of doing the same things are shown.

results.title: Crime: senior alert
results.creator_credit: Gordon Kerkhoff, AIMS Instructional Media and Ronald Floethe
results.brief_description: Crime against the elderly is on the increase. This film offers sensible information which, if followed, will help protect them against the potential criminal. Gives tips on preventing residential burglary, purse snatchers, developing safe car habits and avoiding high-risk areas.

results.title: Crime over London
results.creator_credit: Marcel Hellman, Criterion Ltd and Alfred Zeisler
results.brief_description: A British drama revolving around a store owner who shelters gangsters trying to evade the law. Cast includes Margot Grahame, Paul Cavanagh, Joseph Cawthorn, Basil Sydney and Rene Ray. Written by Norman Alexander and Harold French, based on the novel ‘House of a Thousand Windows’ by Louis De Wohl. Photographed by Victor Armenise and Claude Friese-Greene. Edited by Conrad von Molo.

results.title: Crime on the streets
results.brief_description: This film recounts the high occurence of street crimes, including theft, burglary, assault and rape. Shows how the behaviour of victim often encourages criminals. Suggests ways of protecting the individuals as well as his/her property from attack. Featuring an interview with Chuck Norris.

results.title: Crime and the criminal
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great Themes of Literature”.
Edited from Richard Brooks’ film ‘In Cold Blood’, an adaptation of Truman Capote’s novel which explores the inner life of a criminal. A sensitive probe into the factors that may have created the criminal, considering how is different from the rest of society and questions the use of the death penalty.

results.title: Cries from within
results.brief_description: Looks at new cults and new forms of self-discovery which young people in North America are embracing. Group dynamics, encounter groups, transcendental meditation, Eastern philosophy, communal living, return to nature, re-energised evangelism - all are roads to salvation according to the individual belief.

results.title: Cricket story
results.brief_description: Cricket in Australia from the early days to the 1961 Australian tour team, including an interview with Sir Donald Bradman, who discusses the factors behind Australia’s success in cricket. School cricket, expert coaching, Sheffield Shield matches and selection for Test cricket. The last match of the 1961 series with the West Indies at the Melbourne Cricket Ground, and the memories and traditions associated with Test cricket.

results.title: Cricket in Australia (Captioned)
results.brief_description: From the time of the first test, through days of Aboriginal teams visiting England, the drama of the bodyline series, and the 1977 World Cricket Series Revolution, Australians have always been “cricket mad”. Jack Egan brings together cricket greats to recall highlights of their career, as well as using magnificent archival footage. Special appearances by Ian Chappell, Bill O’Reilly and Lindsay Hassett.
